sets.title: JavaScript Basics
sets.description: Variables, data types, operators, and basic syntax

questions.question: How do you declare a variable in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: Variables in JavaScript are declared using 'var', 'let', or 'const' keywords.

questions.question: Which of these is NOT a primitive data type in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: Object is not a primitive data type. The primitive types are string, number, boolean, null, undefined, symbol, and bigint.

questions.question: What does '===' operator do in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: The '===' operator performs strict comparison, checking both value and data type.

questions.question: What does the 'let' keyword do in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: 'let' declares a block-scoped variable that can be reassigned.

questions.question: What is the difference between 'var' and 'let'?
questions.explanation: 'let' has block scope while 'var' has function scope. 'let' is the modern way to declare variables.

questions.question: What keyword creates a constant variable?
questions.explanation: The 'const' keyword creates a constant variable that cannot be reassigned.

questions.question: Which operator is used for strict inequality in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: The '!==' operator checks for strict inequality (value and type).

questions.question: What is the output of console.log(typeof null) in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: typeof null returns 'object' due to a historical bug in JavaScript.

questions.question: What is the correct way to create an object in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: Objects in JavaScript are created using curly braces {}.

questions.question: What is the correct way to create an array in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: Arrays in JavaScript are created using square brackets [].

questions.question: How do you write a single-line comment in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: Single-line comments in JavaScript start with '//'.

questions.question: How do you write a multi-line comment in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: Multi-line comments in JavaScript are enclosed in /* */ symbols.

questions.question: What is the result of '5' + 3 in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: JavaScript converts the number 3 to a string and concatenates, resulting in '53'.

questions.question: What is the result of '5' - 3 in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: JavaScript converts the string '5' to a number and performs subtraction, resulting in 2.

questions.question: What does NaN stand for?
questions.explanation: NaN stands for 'Not a Number' and represents an invalid number.

questions.question: What is the typeof operator used for?
options: To check the data type of a variable
questions.explanation: The typeof operator returns a string indicating the type of the operand.

questions.question: What is undefined in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: undefined is a primitive value automatically assigned to variables that have been declared but not initialized.

questions.question: What is null in JavaScript?
options: A value representing intentional absence of value
questions.explanation: null is a primitive value that represents the intentional absence of any object value.

questions.question: Which symbol is used for string concatenation in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: The '+' operator is used for string concatenation in JavaScript.

questions.question: What does console.log() do?
options: Displays output in the browser console
questions.explanation: console.log() displays output in the browser's developer console.

sets.title: JavaScript DOM & Events
sets.description: DOM manipulation and event handling in JavaScript

questions.question: Which method is used to select an element by ID?
questions.explanation: getElementById() returns the element with the specified ID.

questions.question: How do you add an event listener to an element?
questions.explanation: addEventListener() is the modern way to attach event handlers to elements.

questions.question: Which property changes the text content of an element?
questions.explanation: textContent sets or returns the text content of the specified element.

questions.question: How do you prevent the default behavior of an event?
questions.explanation: preventDefault() prevents the default action associated with the event.

questions.question: Which method selects all elements with a specific class?
questions.explanation: getElementsByClassName() returns all elements with the specified class name.

questions.question: How do you create a new HTML element?
questions.explanation: createElement() creates a new element with the specified tag name.

questions.question: Which property gets or sets the HTML content of an element?
questions.explanation: innerHTML gets or sets the HTML markup contained within the element.

questions.question: How do you add a CSS class to an element?
questions.explanation: classList.add() adds one or more class names to an element.

questions.question: Which event fires when the page has finished loading?
questions.explanation: The onload event fires when the page has completely loaded.

questions.question: How do you get the value of an input field?
questions.explanation: The value property gets or sets the value of an input field.

questions.question: Which method removes an element from the DOM?
questions.explanation: The remove() method removes the element from the DOM.

questions.question: How do you check if an element has a specific class?
questions.explanation: classList.contains() checks if an element has a specific class.

questions.question: Which event fires when a user clicks on an element?
questions.explanation: The onclick event fires when a user clicks on an element.

questions.question: How do you append a child element to a parent?
questions.explanation: appendChild() appends a child element to the end of the parent's child list.

questions.question: Which property gets the parent element of a node?
questions.explanation: parentNode returns the parent node of the specified element.

questions.question: How do you get all child elements of an element?
questions.explanation: children returns a collection of all child elements.

questions.question: Which method finds the first element matching a CSS selector?
questions.explanation: querySelector() returns the first element that matches the specified CSS selector.

questions.question: How do you set an attribute on an element?
questions.explanation: setAttribute() sets the value of an attribute on the specified element.

questions.question: Which event fires when a form is submitted?
questions.explanation: The onsubmit event fires when a form is submitted.

questions.question: How do you hide an element using JavaScript?
questions.explanation: Setting style.display to 'none' hides the element.

sets.title: JavaScript ES6+ Features
sets.description: Modern JavaScript features from ES6 and beyond

questions.question: What is template literal syntax?
questions.explanation: Template literals use backticks and ${} for variable interpolation.

questions.question: Which keyword creates a constant variable?
questions.explanation: The 'const' keyword creates a constant variable that cannot be reassigned.

questions.question: What is array destructuring?
questions.explanation: Destructuring allows extracting values from arrays into distinct variables.

questions.question: Which operator spreads array elements?
questions.explanation: The spread operator (...) expands array elements.

questions.question: What does Object.assign() do?
questions.explanation: Object.assign() copies enumerable properties from source objects to a target object.

questions.question: Which method creates a new array with transformed elements?
questions.explanation: map() creates a new array with the results of calling a function on every element.

questions.question: What is a Promise in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: A Promise represents the eventual completion or failure of an asynchronous operation.

questions.question: Which keyword makes a function asynchronous?
questions.explanation: The 'async' keyword makes a function return a Promise.

questions.question: What does the 'await' keyword do?
questions.explanation: 'await' pauses function execution until the Promise is resolved.

questions.question: Which method filters array elements?
questions.explanation: filter() creates a new array with elements that pass the test function.

questions.question: What is object destructuring?
questions.explanation: Object destructuring extracts properties from objects into distinct variables.

questions.question: Which method reduces array to single value?
questions.explanation: reduce() executes a reducer function on each element, resulting in a single value.

questions.question: What are default parameters?
questions.explanation: Default parameters allow functions to have default values when no argument is provided.

questions.question: Which creates a class in ES6?
questions.explanation: ES6 introduced the 'class' keyword for creating classes.

questions.question: What is the rest operator?
questions.explanation: The rest operator (...) collects remaining elements into an array.

questions.question: Which method checks if all elements pass a test?
questions.explanation: every() tests whether all elements pass the provided function test.

questions.question: What is a generator function?
options: A function that can pause and resume
A function that generates random numbers
questions.explanation: Generator functions can pause execution and resume later, yielding values.

questions.question: Which symbol creates a generator function?
questions.explanation: function* syntax creates a generator function.

questions.question: What does Set store?
questions.explanation: Set stores unique values of any type.

questions.question: Which creates a Map?
questions.explanation: new Map() creates a new Map object for storing key-value pairs.

sets.title: JavaScript Async & Error Handling
sets.description: Asynchronous programming and error handling in JavaScript

questions.question: Which method handles Promise rejection?
questions.explanation: catch() handles rejected promises.

questions.question: What executes regardless of Promise outcome?
questions.explanation: finally() executes regardless of whether the promise is fulfilled or rejected.

questions.question: Which creates a resolved Promise?
questions.explanation: Promise.resolve() creates a resolved promise with the given value.

questions.question: How do you handle errors in try-catch?
questions.explanation: try-catch-finally is used for error handling in JavaScript.

questions.question: Which method waits for all Promises to resolve?
questions.explanation: Promise.all() waits for all promises to resolve or any to reject.

questions.question: What does setTimeout() do?
questions.explanation: setTimeout() executes a function after a specified delay.

questions.question: Which creates a rejected Promise?
questions.explanation: Promise.reject() creates a rejected promise with the given reason.

questions.question: What is callback hell?
questions.explanation: Callback hell refers to deeply nested callback functions that are hard to read.

questions.question: Which method executes function repeatedly?
questions.explanation: setInterval() calls a function repeatedly at specified intervals.

questions.question: How do you throw a custom error?
questions.explanation: throw new Error() creates and throws a custom error.

questions.question: Which method races multiple Promises?
questions.explanation: Promise.race() returns when the first promise settles (resolves or rejects).

questions.question: What is async/await syntax for?
questions.explanation: async/await provides a cleaner syntax for working with Promises.

questions.question: Which clears a timeout?
questions.explanation: clearTimeout() cancels a timeout previously set with setTimeout().

questions.question: What happens if you don't catch a rejected Promise?
questions.explanation: Unhandled promise rejections generate warnings and may crash the application.

questions.question: Which method settles all Promises regardless of outcome?
questions.explanation: Promise.allSettled() waits for all promises to settle, whether resolved or rejected.

questions.question: How do you convert callback to Promise?
questions.explanation: Wrapping callback code in new Promise() converts it to Promise-based code.

questions.question: What is the Event Loop?
questions.explanation: The Event Loop is JavaScript's concurrency model that handles asynchronous operations.

questions.question: Which queue has higher priority?
questions.explanation: The microtask queue (promises) has higher priority than the callback queue.

questions.question: What is a microtask?
questions.explanation: Microtasks are promise callbacks that have higher priority in the event loop.

questions.question: Which method chains multiple async operations?
questions.explanation: then() is used to chain multiple Promise operations.

questions.question: What is prototypal inheritance?
questions.explanation: In JavaScript, objects can inherit directly from other objects through the prototype chain.

questions.question: Which creates a property descriptor?
questions.explanation: Object.defineProperty() defines or modifies a property with detailed configuration.

questions.question: What is hoisting in JavaScript?
options: Variable and function declarations moved to top
questions.explanation: Hoisting is JavaScript's behavior of moving declarations to the top of their scope.

questions.question: Which method binds a function to an object?
questions.explanation: bind() creates a new function with 'this' bound to the provided object.

questions.question: What is the Module pattern?
questions.explanation: The Module pattern uses closures to create encapsulated, reusable code.

questions.question: Which method calls a function with specific 'this'?
questions.explanation: call() invokes a function with a specific 'this' value and arguments.

questions.question: What is currying in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: Currying transforms a function with multiple arguments into a sequence of single-argument functions.

questions.question: Which creates an object without prototype?
questions.explanation: Object.create(null) creates an object without inheriting from Object.prototype.

questions.question: What is memoization?
questions.explanation: Memoization is an optimization technique that caches function results.

questions.question: Which method applies function with array arguments?
questions.explanation: apply() calls a function with 'this' value and arguments provided as an array.

questions.question: What is a higher-order function?
options: Function that operates on other functions
questions.explanation: A higher-order function takes other functions as arguments or returns functions.

questions.question: Which pattern prevents global pollution?
questions.explanation: IIFE (Immediately Invoked Function Expression) creates a private scope to avoid global pollution.

questions.question: What is the Revealing Module pattern?
questions.explanation: The Revealing Module pattern exposes only the methods and variables you want to be public.

questions.question: Which method freezes an object?
questions.explanation: Object.freeze() prevents modification of existing property values and addition of new properties.

questions.question: What is the difference between call() and apply()?
options: call() takes individual arguments, apply() takes array
questions.explanation: call() takes arguments individually, while apply() takes them as an array.

questions.question: Which method gets property names of object?
questions.explanation: Object.keys() returns an array of object's own enumerable property names.

questions.question: What is a pure function?
questions.explanation: A pure function has no side effects and always returns the same output for the same input.

questions.question: Which creates a shallow copy of object?
questions.explanation: Object.assign() creates a shallow copy by copying enumerable properties.

questions.question: What is debouncing?
questions.explanation: Debouncing delays function execution until after a specified time has passed since the last call.

questions.question: Which method checks if property exists?
questions.explanation: hasOwnProperty() checks if an object has a specific property as its own (not inherited).

sets.title: JavaScript Functions & Scope
sets.description: Function declarations, expressions, scope, and closures

questions.question: What is function hoisting?
options: Functions are moved to top of scope
questions.explanation: Function declarations are hoisted to the top of their containing scope.

questions.question: What is the difference between function declaration and expression?
options: Declarations are hoisted, expressions are not
questions.explanation: Function declarations are fully hoisted, while function expressions are not hoisted.

questions.question: What is lexical scope?
options: Scope determined by where variables are declared
questions.explanation: Lexical scope means scope is determined by where variables and blocks of scope are authored.

questions.question: What happens when you call a function with fewer arguments than parameters?
questions.explanation: Missing parameters are set to undefined.

questions.question: What is an IIFE?
questions.explanation: IIFE stands for Immediately Invoked Function Expression - a function that runs as soon as it's defined.

questions.question: Which creates a function expression?
questions.explanation: var foo = function() {} creates a function expression assigned to a variable.

questions.question: What is the arguments object?
questions.explanation: The arguments object is an array-like object available within functions containing all passed arguments.

questions.question: What does 'use strict' do?
options: Enables strict mode with stricter error checking
questions.explanation: 'use strict' enables strict mode, which catches more errors and prevents certain unsafe actions.

questions.question: What is a named function expression?
questions.explanation: A named function expression has a name that's only accessible within the function itself.

questions.question: What is function scope?
options: Variables declared in function are accessible anywhere
Variables declared in function are only accessible within that function
questions.explanation: Function scope means variables declared within a function are only accessible within that function.

questions.question: What happens with nested functions and scope?
options: Inner functions cannot access outer variables
Inner functions can access outer function variables
questions.explanation: Inner functions have access to variables in their outer (enclosing) function scope.

questions.question: What is the temporal dead zone?
options: Period where let/const variables exist but cannot be accessed
questions.explanation: The temporal dead zone is the time between entering scope and the variable declaration being reached.

questions.question: What is function.length property?
options: Number of parameters expected by function
questions.explanation: The length property indicates the number of parameters expected by the function.

questions.question: What is a callback function?
options: Function passed as argument to another function
questions.explanation: A callback function is a function passed into another function as an argument.

questions.question: What is function recursion?
questions.explanation: Recursion occurs when a function calls itself, typically with different parameters.

questions.question: What is the difference between call(), apply(), and bind()?
options: call() and apply() invoke immediately, bind() returns new function
questions.explanation: call() and apply() invoke the function immediately, while bind() returns a new function with bound context.

questions.question: What is method chaining?
questions.explanation: Method chaining allows multiple method calls on the same object by returning 'this'.

questions.question: What is a pure function?
options: Function that always returns same output for same input with no side effects
questions.explanation: A pure function always produces the same output for the same input and has no side effects.

questions.question: What is function overloading in JavaScript?
questions.explanation: JavaScript doesn't support true function overloading - the last function definition overwrites previous ones.

questions.question: What is the 'new' operator used for?
options: Creating new objects from constructor functions
questions.explanation: The 'new' operator creates a new object instance from a constructor function.

sets.title: JavaScript Objects & Prototypes
sets.description: Object creation, prototypes, inheritance, and methods

questions.question: What is a prototype in JavaScript?
options: Object from which other objects inherit properties
questions.explanation: A prototype is an object from which other objects inherit properties and methods.

questions.question: How do you add a method to all instances of a constructor?
questions.explanation: Adding methods to Constructor.prototype makes them available to all instances.

questions.question: What is the prototype chain?
options: Linked list of prototypes for inheritance
questions.explanation: The prototype chain is a series of links between objects used for inheritance.

questions.question: What does Object.create() do?
questions.explanation: Object.create() creates a new object with the specified prototype object.

questions.question: What is the difference between __proto__ and prototype?
options: __proto__ is instance property, prototype is constructor property
questions.explanation: __proto__ is a property of object instances, prototype is a property of constructor functions.

questions.question: What is Object.getPrototypeOf()?
options: Gets the prototype of an object
questions.explanation: Object.getPrototypeOf() returns the prototype of the specified object.

questions.question: How do you check if an object has a property?
questions.explanation: hasOwnProperty() checks if an object has a specific property as its own (not inherited).

questions.question: What is Object.keys()?
questions.explanation: Object.keys() returns an array of an object's own enumerable property names.

questions.question: What is Object.values()?
questions.explanation: Object.values() returns an array of an object's own enumerable property values.

questions.question: What is Object.entries()?
questions.explanation: Object.entries() returns an array of [key, value] pairs for each enumerable property.

questions.question: What is a constructor function?
options: Function used with 'new' to create objects
questions.explanation: A constructor function is used with 'new' to create and initialize objects.

questions.question: What happens if you forget 'new' with constructor?
questions.explanation: Without 'new', 'this' refers to the global object (or undefined in strict mode).

questions.question: What is Object.assign()?
options: Copies properties from source to target object
questions.explanation: Object.assign() copies enumerable properties from one or more source objects to a target.

questions.question: What is the 'in' operator?
options: Checks if value is in array
Checks if property exists in object
Checks if object is in array
Checks if function is in object
questions.explanation: The 'in' operator checks if a property exists in an object (including inherited properties).

questions.question: What is Object.freeze()?
questions.explanation: Object.freeze() prevents modification of existing properties and addition of new properties.

questions.question: What is Object.seal()?
options: Prevents addition/deletion of properties but allows modification
questions.explanation: Object.seal() prevents adding or removing properties but allows modification of existing ones.

questions.question: What is property descriptor?
questions.explanation: A property descriptor is an object that describes the configuration of a property.

questions.question: What is Object.defineProperty()?
options: Defines or modifies property with detailed configuration
questions.explanation: Object.defineProperty() defines a new property or modifies an existing one with detailed configuration.

questions.question: What are getters and setters?
questions.explanation: Getters and setters are functions that allow you to define how properties are accessed and modified.

questions.question: What is instanceof operator?
options: Checks if object is instance of constructor
questions.explanation: instanceof checks if an object is an instance of a specific constructor function.

sets.title: JavaScript Arrays & Iteration
sets.description: Array methods, iteration techniques, and functional programming

questions.question: What does Array.isArray() do?
options: Checks if value is an array
questions.explanation: Array.isArray() determines whether the passed value is an array.

questions.question: What is the difference between map() and forEach()?
options: map() returns new array, forEach() returns undefined
questions.explanation: map() creates and returns a new array, while forEach() returns undefined.

questions.question: What does Array.from() do?
options: Creates array from array-like or iterable object
questions.explanation: Array.from() creates a new Array instance from an array-like or iterable object.

questions.question: What is the spread operator with arrays?
questions.explanation: The spread operator (...) expands array elements in places where multiple elements are expected.

questions.question: What does filter() method return?
options: New array with elements that pass the test
questions.explanation: filter() returns a new array containing only elements that pass the provided test function.

questions.question: What does reduce() method do?
options: Executes reducer function on each element, resulting in single value
questions.explanation: reduce() executes a reducer function on each array element, returning a single output value.

questions.question: What is the difference between find() and filter()?
options: find() returns first match, filter() returns all matches
questions.explanation: find() returns the first element that matches, filter() returns all elements that match.

questions.question: What does some() method return?
options: true if at least one element passes test
questions.explanation: some() returns true if at least one element passes the provided test function.

questions.question: What does every() method return?
options: true if all elements pass test
questions.explanation: every() returns true if all elements pass the provided test function.

questions.question: What is Array.concat()?
questions.explanation: concat() merges two or more arrays and returns a new array.

questions.question: What does slice() method do?
options: Returns shallow copy of portion of array
questions.explanation: slice() returns a shallow copy of a portion of an array without modifying the original.

questions.question: What does splice() method do?
questions.explanation: splice() changes array contents by removing/replacing existing elements and/or adding new ones.

questions.question: What is the difference between slice() and splice()?
options: slice() doesn't modify original, splice() does
questions.explanation: slice() returns a copy without modifying original, splice() modifies the original array.

questions.question: What does join() method return?
options: String with all array elements joined
questions.explanation: join() creates and returns a string by concatenating all array elements.

questions.question: What does reverse() method do?
questions.explanation: reverse() reverses the array elements in place and returns the reference to the same array.

questions.question: What does sort() method do by default?
questions.explanation: sort() converts elements to strings and sorts them alphabetically by default.

questions.question: What is indexOf() method?
questions.explanation: indexOf() returns the first index at which a given element can be found in the array.

questions.question: What does includes() method return?
questions.explanation: includes() returns true if the array contains the specified element, false otherwise.

questions.question: What is Array destructuring?
questions.explanation: Array destructuring allows extracting array values into distinct variables in a single statement.

questions.question: What does flat() method do?
questions.explanation: flat() creates a new array with sub-array elements concatenated into it recursively.

sets.title: JavaScript Modules & Classes
sets.description: ES6 modules, import/export, class syntax and inheritance

questions.question: What is ES6 module syntax?
questions.explanation: ES6 uses import/export syntax for module system.

questions.question: What is default export?
questions.explanation: Default export is the main export from a module, imported without curly braces.

questions.question: How do you import everything from a module?
questions.explanation: import * as name imports all exports from a module into a namespace object.

questions.question: What is named export?
options: Export that must be imported with exact name
questions.explanation: Named exports must be imported using the exact exported name (or with alias).

questions.question: What is class syntax in ES6?
questions.explanation: ES6 classes use the 'class' keyword followed by the class name and curly braces.

questions.question: What is a constructor in class?
options: Special method called when instance is created
questions.explanation: Constructor is a special method that's automatically called when a new instance is created.

questions.question: What is class inheritance?
questions.explanation: Class inheritance allows a class to inherit properties and methods from another class using 'extends'.

questions.question: What is super() keyword?
questions.explanation: super() calls the constructor or methods of the parent class.

questions.question: What are static methods?
options: Methods called on class itself, not instances
questions.explanation: Static methods are called on the class itself rather than on instances of the class.

questions.question: What are private fields in classes?
options: Fields prefixed with # that are only accessible within class
questions.explanation: Private fields are prefixed with # and are only accessible within the class that defines them.

questions.question: What is method overriding?
options: Child class providing different implementation of parent method
questions.explanation: Method overriding occurs when a subclass provides a different implementation of a method from its parent class.

questions.question: What is the difference between class and function constructor?
options: Class uses 'class' keyword and has cleaner syntax
questions.explanation: Classes provide cleaner syntax and additional features compared to function constructors.

questions.question: What are getter and setter in classes?
questions.explanation: Getters and setters are special methods that provide access to object properties with custom logic.

questions.question: What is module loading?
options: Process of importing and executing modules
questions.explanation: Module loading is the process by which JavaScript engines import and execute modules.

questions.question: What is tree shaking?
questions.explanation: Tree shaking is the process of removing unused code from JavaScript bundles.

questions.question: What is dynamic import?
options: import() function for runtime module loading
questions.explanation: Dynamic imports use the import() function to load modules at runtime.

questions.question: What is re-export?
questions.explanation: Re-export allows you to export something that was imported from another module.

questions.question: What is module namespace?
options: Object containing all exports from module
questions.explanation: Module namespace is an object that contains all the exports from a module.

questions.question: What are abstract classes?
questions.explanation: JavaScript doesn't have built-in support for abstract classes, but patterns can simulate them.

questions.question: What is mixin pattern?
questions.explanation: Mixins are a pattern for achieving multiple inheritance by copying properties from multiple sources.

sets.title: JavaScript Performance & Best Practices
sets.description: Optimization techniques, debugging, and modern JavaScript practices

questions.question: What is lazy loading?
questions.explanation: Lazy loading defers the loading of resources until they are actually needed.

questions.question: What is code splitting?
options: Breaking code into smaller, loadable chunks
questions.explanation: Code splitting breaks your code into smaller chunks that can be loaded on demand.

questions.question: What is minification?
options: Making code smaller by removing unnecessary characters
questions.explanation: Minification reduces file size by removing whitespace, comments, and shortening variable names.

questions.question: What is the purpose of Source Maps?
options: Map original source code to minified code for debugging
questions.explanation: Source maps allow debugging of minified code by mapping it back to original source.

questions.question: What is throttling?
questions.explanation: Throttling limits the rate at which a function can be executed.

questions.question: What is debouncing?
options: Delaying function execution until after delay period
questions.explanation: Debouncing delays function execution until after a wait period since the last call.

questions.question: What is memory leak?
options: Memory that cannot be garbage collected
questions.explanation: Memory leaks occur when memory that's no longer needed isn't released for reuse.

questions.question: What causes memory leaks in JavaScript?
options: Circular references, global variables, event listeners not removed
questions.explanation: Common causes include circular references, unremoved event listeners, and global variables.

questions.question: What is garbage collection?
questions.explanation: Garbage collection is JavaScript's automatic memory management that frees unused memory.

questions.question: What is the console.time() method for?
options: Measuring execution time of code blocks
questions.explanation: console.time() and console.timeEnd() measure how long code takes to execute.

questions.question: What is profiling?
questions.explanation: Profiling analyzes code to identify performance bottlenecks and optimization opportunities.

questions.question: What is the performance.now() method?
questions.explanation: performance.now() provides high-precision timestamps for accurate performance measurement.

questions.question: What is bundling?
options: Combining multiple files into single file
questions.explanation: Bundling combines multiple JavaScript files into a single file for deployment.

questions.question: What is webpack?
questions.explanation: Webpack is a popular module bundler that processes and bundles web assets.

questions.question: What is linting?
options: Static code analysis for errors and style issues
questions.explanation: Linting analyzes code for potential errors, bugs, and style issues.

questions.question: What is ESLint?
questions.explanation: ESLint is a popular linting tool for identifying and fixing JavaScript code issues.

questions.question: What is Prettier?
questions.explanation: Prettier is an opinionated code formatter that ensures consistent code style.

questions.question: What is the difference between development and production builds?
options: Development includes debugging tools, production is optimized
questions.explanation: Development builds include debugging tools and are unminified, production builds are optimized.

questions.question: What are environment variables?
questions.explanation: Environment variables are system-level variables used for application configuration.

questions.question: What is the importance of semantic versioning?
questions.explanation: Semantic versioning uses version numbers to communicate the nature of changes in software releases.
